What kind of maneuvers do you want to access?

The obstruction of the airway by a foreign object or chocking occurs when food or an object gets accidentally stuck in the airway and prevents air from entering the lungs causing asphyxiation. Most obstructions are mild but others can cause the victim to enter into cardiac arrest due to lack of oxygen resulting in death.

The best way to resolve this health problem is to provide training to people on prevention and the quick action procedures to be used when someone is choking.

A. These are basic prevention measures for adults:

  • cut food into small pieces;
  • chew food slowly and thoroughly, especially if you are using dental prosthetics;
  • do not laugh while your are chewing and swallowing;
  • avoid ingesting excessive amounts of alcohol before and during meals.

    • In the case of babies and children:

  • keep marbles, beads, thumbtacks, latex balloons, coins and other small toys or objects out of the reach of children, especially children younger than 3;
  • prevent children from walking, running or playing with food or toys in their mouths;
  • supervise children when they are eating and in children under 4 years old, avoid giving them food that may get lodged in their throat such as hot dogs, walnuts, chunks of meat, chinks of cheese, grapes, hard or sticky candy and popcorn;
  • ensure that older children do not give dangerous food or toys to smaller children;
  • as a rule of thumb, remember that you should not give children small toys or objects that can fit through the hole of a toilet paper roll.

B. The entire population should be familiar with the procedures and maneuvers required in case of choking.
